title: Modeling Data: Profits
question_text: Which equation would be the best to model the data?
solution:
First, plot the data to see the form is clearly exponential. Alternatively, one could calculate the correlation coefficient of $(\text{year}, \text{profits})$, and also calculate the correlation between $(\text{year}, \log (\text{profits}))$ to see $(\text{year}, \log (\text{profits}))$ has a higher $r$-value.

Once it is obvious that the data has exponential form, take the log of the $y$-values (profit) to linearize the data given in the table of the prompt.

Computer printout or a calculator will show the equation (rounded):

$$\log{\text{(Profits)}} = 0.09 {\text{(Year)}} + 0.15$$

Via TI 83/84 graphing calculator:

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
